Selective hydrogenation of diphenyl ethers over NiCo bimetallic catalyst Dayi Guo Conceptualization Methodology Writing – original draft a Shuai Wang Validation Data curation a Junfeng Feng Visualization Supervision a b Hui Pan Project administration Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing a b ⁎ a Jiangsu Co-Innovation Center of Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Resources, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, PR China Jiangsu Co-Innovation Center of Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Resources, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University Nanjing 210037 PR China aJiangsu Co-Innovation Center of Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Resources, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, PR China b Jiangsu Province Key Laboratory of Green Biomass-based Fuels and Chemicals, Nanjing 210037, PR China Jiangsu Province Key Laboratory of Green Biomass-based Fuels and Chemicals Nanjing 210037 PR China bJiangsu Province Key Laboratory of Green Biomass-based Fuels and Chemicals, Nanjing 210037, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Jiangsu Co-Innovation Center of Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Resources, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, PR China. Jiangsu Co-Innovation Center of Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Resources, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University Nanjing 210037 PR China The selective cleavage of ether bonds by non-noble metal catalysts is crucial for the valorization of lignin. Bimetallic catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation using SiO2-Al2O3 as the supports and Ni and Co as the active metal sites. The prepared bimetal catalysts possess higher catalytic activity than single Ni or Co catalysts and could efficiently cleave the CO bonds of diphenyl ether (DPE), under relatively mild conditions (160 °C, 1 MPa H2, 2 h). The XPS characterization suggested the interactions between Ni and Co in the bimetal catalysts, which could bring synergy effects between metals and increase the catalytic activity. The H2-TPR analysis confirmed that the presence of Ni lowered the reduction temperature of Co oxides in the bimetallic xNiyCo/SA catalyst compared to the monometallic Co/SA catalyst, which would increase the amount of metallic Co. Based on the product distribution, it could be proposed that the hydrogenation of DPE over catalyst 15Ni15Co/SA was mainly via the reaction path of “partial hydrogenation-hydrogenolysis-hydrogenation" process. The catalytic activity of catalyst15Ni15Co/SA could be recovered after regeneration. It also exhibited versatility for the cleavage of other CO bonds. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords DPE Hydrogenolysis C-O bond Interaction NiCo alloys Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lignin, as a natural aromatic polymer, can be obtained from regenerated lignocellulosic biomass [1–3]. The conversion of lignin and its derivatives has good application prospects in the future [4,5]. The main chemical bonds presented in lignin structures include CO bonds (e.g., β-O-4, α-O-4 and 4-O-5) and CC bonds (e.g., β-β, β−5, β−1, and 5–5) [6], in which ether bonds are the most abundant, accounting for about 80% of the total bonds in lignin structures. Among these ether bonds, 4-O-5 type of ether bond possess higher bond energy than those of bonds and therefore it takes severer conditions to break 4-O-5 bonds. For instance, diphenyl ether (DPE) is a typical model compound for 4-O-5 bonds which has a high bond dissociation energy [7,8]. In general, the catalytic cleavage of aryl ether bond can be realized by hydrogenation [9], hydrolysis [10], and hydrogenolysis [11]. Noble metal catalysts, including Pt [12–14], Ru [15–17], and Pd [18,19], have been extensively researched for the hydrogenolysis of DPE. Despite their distinctive catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of DPE (Table S1), the high costs of noble metals have limited their industrial applications. To find efficient non-noble metal catalysts for hydrogenation reactions is highly desired. According to literature reports, Ni and Co are transition metals and abundant in nature. Ni and Co-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity in hydrogenation and CO bond cleavage, giving Ni and Co the potential to replace noble metal catalysts. For example, Jiang et al. [20] reported a Ni/Nb2O5 catalyst could efficiently promote the cleavage of CO bonds of DPE under optimal reaction conditions (220 °C, 1 MPa H2, 2 h). Song et al. [21] synthesized a Co/C@N catalyst for the selective hydrogenolysis of Calk-O bonds in lignin-derived aryl ether under optimal reaction conditions (160 °C, 2 MPa H2, 2 h). Wang and Rinaldi [22] investigated the hydrogenolysis of diphenyl ether and lignin with Raney Ni as the catalyst. The yield of hydrogenolysis was less than 50% at 90 °C, 5 MPa H2, and 2.5 h. Bimetallic catalysts can change the surface properties of each metal components compared to that in monometallic catalysts, which would enhance the catalytic activity of the resulting catalysts, change the selectivity of desired products, and also improve the stability of the catalyst [23]. Marin et al. [24] using bimetallic FeNi3@Ni catalysts for the selective hydrogenolysis of DPE, which could achieve 93% efficiency of hydrogenolysis at 180 °C and 0.3 MPa H2. What's more, the performance of a catalyst depends not only on the active metal, but also on the choice of the support [25]. Carefully chosen support materials can increase the number of active sites and introduce necessary functions to the catalyst [26]. Among commonly used catalyst supports, silica could reduce the agglomeration of metal nanoparticles owing to its hydrophilic surface and chemical inertness [27,28], and is often used in hydrogenation [29], oxidation [30], hydrodeoxygenation [31]; On the other hand, surface modifications are usually need to introduce other functional sites when pure silica was used as the catalyst support due to its low specific surface area and neutral pH [32]. It is well known that acidic sites contribute to the hydrogenation reactions of ether bonds [33–35]. Al2O3 is another common used catalyst support for its sufficient acidic sites, microporosity, large specific surface area and excellent physical strength [36]. However, Al2O3 is less thermally stable and it may undergo phase transitions at different temperatures, which might cause decrease in its specific surface area [37]. On the other hand, mixing of metal oxides as catalyst support can tune the acidity, thermal stability, specific surface area and reduction properties of the original support, and greatly improve the structure and activity of the catalyst in the reaction [38–40]. In this work, bimetallic catalysts were prepared using nickel and cobalt as the metal active sites and SiO2-Al2O3 (SA) as the support by wet impregnation method. SiO2-Al2O3 (SA) was chosen as the catalyst support due to its high specific surface area, high porosity, thermal stability and rich in acidic site [41,42]. The catalytic performance of the as prepared bimetallic catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of DPE was studied. The structure, morphology and chemical state of the catalyst are characterized by a series of characterization methods. The possible reaction pathway of the DPE hydrogenolysis were proposed according to the distribution of products. Finally, the stability and universality of the catalyst were evaluated. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials and reagents SiO2-Al2O3 (SA) was purchased from Saint-Gobain NorPro, USA. Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate [Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.0%], nickel nitrate hexahydrate [Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.0%], diphenyl ether (DPE) [C12H10O, 99.5%], 1,4-dioxane (Diox) [C4H8O2, 99.5%], benzene (BEN) [C6H6, 99.5%], cyclohexanol (CHL) [C6H12O, 98.0%], phenol (PHL) [C6H6O, 99.0%], cyclohexane (CHN) [C6H12, 99.5%], isopropanol (IPA) [C3H8O, 99.0%], ethanol (EtOH) [C2H6O, 99.0%], Methanol (MeOH) [CH3OH, 99.0%], N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) [C3H7NO, 99.0%], Al2O3 and SiO2 were purchased from local Sinopharm Chemical Reagent. 2.2 Catalyst preparation All the NiCo catalysts in this study with varied metal loading (0–30wt%) were prepared by wet impregnation method. A typical preparation process is as follows: about 1 g of SA powder, desired amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and/or Co(NO3)2·6H2O were added to a beaker followed by the addition of 40 mL deionized water. The above mixture was allowed to stir quickly under ambient condition till most water was evaporated (about 6–8 h). The mixture was then further dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The resulting power was first calcined at 500 °C with a heating rate of 3 °C/min in a Muffle furnace for 4 h. Calcined powder was then reduced in a tube furnace under a reduction atmosphere (N2:H2 =9:1, v/v). Three different temperatures (500 °C, 600 °C, 700 °C) was investigated for the reducing process at the same heating rate of 3 °C/min and time of 4 h. The obtained catalysts were denoted as xNiyCo/SA, where x and y refer to the weight percentages of Ni and Co in the catalyst, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The catalyst characterization is detailed in the supporting material. 2.4 Hydrogenation reactions of DPE The hydrogenation reaction was conducted in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical reaction process, 1 mmol DPE, 100 mg catalyst, 20 mL 1,4-dioxane were added into the autoclave. The autoclave was purged with H2 for 3 times to expel the air. Finally, the pressure of the autoclave was purged to 1 MPa with H2 and the temperature was raised to 120∼200 °C and kept for 1–7 h depending on designed reaction conditions with continuous stir at 600 rpm. Upon the end of the reaction, a total of 25 mL of 1,4-dioxane was added to the reaction mixture for quantitative analysis of reaction products by using a gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7890A) equipped with an FID detector and HP-INNOWAX capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and GS-MS (Agilent 7890A, DB-5MS capillary column, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). Dodecane (135 mg) was added as the internal standard. Benzene (BEN), cyclohexanol (CHL), phenol (PHL), cyclohexane (CHE), cyclohexyl phenyl ether (CPE) and di-cyclohexyl ether (DCE) were identified as the main products of DPE hydrogenation. The conversion of DPE and selectivity of product are calculated as follows: (1) Conversio n DPE = moles of reactant converted initial moles of reactant × 100 % (2) Selectivit y i = moles of a certain product total moles of products obtained × 100 % Where i represents the product after reaction (i.e., BEN, CHL, PHL, CHE, CPE and DCE). For the catalyst recycle experiment, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, and then the separated catalyst was washed 3∼5 times by ethanol and dried overnight in the oven, and the obtained solid powder was used for the cycle experiment. In addition, the catalyst after the fifth reaction is regenerated by the reduction of hydrogen, and then the catalyst is used for the sixth recycle experiment. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The physicochemical property of all samples in the experiment was listed in Table 1 , all metal-loaded on SA support catalysts showed slightly decreased surface area and pore volume compared to that of the SA support while the pore size remained relatively constant, indicated the low extent of pore blockage with metal loading process. The low-temperature nitrogen adsorption and desorption of all catalysts exhibited type I adsorption isotherm curves with H4 type hysteresis loop (Fig. 1 a) [43], suggested the co-existence of both microspores and mesopores in the catalysts. The similar pore size distributions of the catalysts and SA support (Fig. 1b) obtained by the NLDFT equation also confirmed that the impregnation process did not affect the mesoporous structures of the catalysts [44]. The crystal phase analysis of the catalyst and support was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in Fig. 2 a, all metal loaded catalysts and SA support exhibited diffraction peaks at 21.98°, 45.79°, and 66.76°, which are characteristic peaks of SiO2 (PDF#04–0379) and Al2O3 (PDF#01–1303). For the 30Ni/SA catalyst, three typical diffraction peaks of around 2θ at 44.6°, 51.9° and 76.8° belongs to the (111), (200) and (220) plane of Ni (PDF # 01–1260), respectively. For the 30Co/SA catalyst, a weak diffraction peak around 2θ at 44.3° belongs to the (111) plane of metal Co (PDF#01–1255). Compared to the 30Co/SA and 30Ni/SA catalysts, the diffraction peaks of Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts are located between individual metal Ni and metal Co (Fig. 2b), indicating the formation of Ni-Co alloys [45]. It has been reported that the formation of metal alloy could improve enhance the catalytic activity and create a synergistic/bifunctional effect [23], which may play a good role in the selective hydrogenation of diphenyl ether. The diffraction peaks of Ni-Co alloys can be observed in the XRD patterns of most bimetallic catalysts with different metal loading ratios except for the 2Ni2Co/SA catalyst (Fig. S1). The dispersion of metals in 15Ni15Co/SA catalysts was further analyzed by TEM (Transmission electron microscope). As shown in Fig. 3 a, the average particle size of the Ni-Co alloy in the 15Ni15Co/SA catalyst is about 19 ± 6.06 nm without any agglomeration. As presented in Fig. 3b, the crystal plane separation of 0.204 nm is in good agreement with the (111) plane of the Ni-Co alloy [46], which is consistent with the XRD analysis results. The HRTEM image and HRTEM elemental mappings of 15Ni15Co/SA (Fig. 3c–h) demonstrate that the Ni and Co metals are dispersed on the surface of the supports and scattered in roughly the same place. In order to understand the electronic structure and chemical valent states, the catalysts were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 4 a and 4b displayed the Co 2p3/2 and Ni 2p3/2 XPS spectra, respectively, of the catalysts with different metal loadings. The Co 2p3/2 spectrum of mono-metal catalyst 30Co/SA can be deconvolved into four peaks at binding energies of 779.1, 780.8, 782.8, and 786.0 eV, corresponding to Co0, Co3+, Co2+, and the satellite peak of Co2+, respectively [47,48]. The same Co species are also presented in the bimetallic catalyst with different Co and Ni metal loadings. However, the binding energies corresponding to Co0 in all bimetallic catalysts 10Ni20Co/SA, 15Ni15Co/SA and 20Ni10Co/SA show a significant blue shift compared to that in mono-metal catalyst 30Co/SA, suggesting the increased electron density of Co. For the other mono-metal loaded catalyst 30Ni/SA, the Ni 2p3/2 spectrum also can be deconvolved into four peaks with binding energies of 852.4, 854.5, 856.2, and 861.4 eV, corresponding to Ni0, Ni2+, and the satellite peak of Ni2+, respectively [49,50]. Unlike that of the Co species, the binding energy of Ni0 in the Ni 2p3/2 spectra of the bimetallic catalysts showed a significant red shift compared to the mono-metal loaded 30Ni/SA, indicating the decreased electron density of Ni. The increased electron density of Co and the decreased electron density of Ni indicates the formation of Ni-Co alloys [45,51], which is consistent with the XRD characterization results, and there is a synergy between Ni and Co metals [52,53]. From the results in Figs. S2 and S3, with the addition of Ni and Co metals, it can be seen that compared to the 30Co/SA catalyst, the binding energy of Si 2p and Al 2p [54] is basically consistent with the binding energy of Si and Al in SA, which indicates that there is a strong interaction between the metal Co and the support. To analyze the interactions between the metals and the support, H2-TPR profiles of different catalysts were compared in Fig. 5 . It has been reported that according to the different reduction temperatures, the species of Ni and Co can be divided into three types (α, β, and γ) [55]. An α-type reduction peak was found at a lower temperature (308 °C) for catalyst 30Co/SA, which is corresponded to the reducing of Co3O4 to CoO. A weak reduction peak appears at high temperatures (500 °C), corresponding to the reduction of CoO to Co [56]. A strong β-type reduction peak at 735 °C was also observed, indicated the presence of strong interaction between the Co species and the support in catalyst 30Co/SA. No γ-type reduction peaks (750–850 °C) were observed in the H2-TPR curve of catalyst 30Co/SA, suggested the absence of less reducible CoAl2O4 species [57], which is consisted with that of the XRD analysis. An α-type peak positioned at a lower temperature (207 °C) in the H2-TPR curve of catalyst 30Ni/SA, which is ascribed to the superficial NiO to Ni0 [58]. Another weak reduction peak was also observed at 696 °C, which should be a β-type reduction peak ascribed to the Ni species that possess strong interaction with the support and are hard to be reduced [59]. With the increase of Ni metal loading in the bimetallic catalysts, both the corresponding α- and β-type reduction peaks move to the lower temperature regions, indicating the increase of Ni metal loading in the bimetallic catalysts could enhance its reducing activity. With the increase of Ni metal loading in the bimetallic catalysts, both the corresponding α- and β-type reduction peaks move to the lower temperature regions, indicating the increase of Ni metal loading in the bimetallic catalysts could enhance its reducing activity. Consequently, the amount of metallic Co would increase, which would in turn facilitate the adsorption of H and dissociation of H2 [60,61]. 3.2 Hydrogenation of DPE As shown in Table 2 , CHL and CHE were the main products of DPE hydrogenolysis. The conversion of DPE was negligible when the SA support was used as a catalyst. After the metals (Ni and Co) were supported on the SA, all catalysts exhibit different degrees of catalytic activity. Under the same reaction condition, catalysts 15Ni15Co/SA (Table 2, entry 4) showed higher DPE conversion than monometallic catalysts 30Ni/SA and 30Co/SA (Table 2, entry 7–8). When Ni and Co low loading, the poor catalytic activity was due to the lack of Ni-Co alloys, which was confirmed by the XRD results (Fig. S1). However, due to the formation of Ni-Co alloys, the catalytic activity was also significantly improved (Table 2, entry 3–5). The catalyst activity decreases with the loading of Ni and Co reaches at 30wt% (Table 2, entry 6), which may be the aggregation of the Ni-Co alloy, and can also be explained by the Ni-Co alloy diffraction peak intensity in the 30Ni30Co/SA and 22Ni22Co/SA catalysts (Fig. S1). The hydrogenation performance of the bimetallic catalysts at different ratio of Ni and Co was also explored by keeping the total amount of Ni and Co at 30wt% (Table 2, entry 7–8), which indicated that the different ratios of Ni and Co had no obvious effect on the activity of the catalyst. In addition, the physical mixture of catalysts 15Ni/SA and 15Co/SA gave lower conversion of DPE and different product selectivity (Table 2, entry 11) than that of the bimetallic catalyst 15Ni15Co/SA (Table 2, entry 4). The above result illustrated the synergistic effect between Ni and Co in the bimetallic catalysts. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of the catalysts using single metal oxide support have also been explored (Table 2, entry 12–13). It can be seen that neither Al2O3 nor SiO2 supported catalyst provided sufficient conversion of diphenyl ether compared to the mixed oxides support SiO2-Al2O3, suggesting that single support Al2O3 and SiO2 were not suitable support for the Ni-Co bimetal catalyst in the hydrogenation reaction of DPE. The effect of DPE hydrogenation under different reaction conditions was explored using 15Ni15Co/SA as a catalyst. Firstly, the effect of the reaction time on the activity of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 6 a. The conversion of DPE first increases and then remains constant with increasing reaction time. When the reaction time reaches 2 h, the conversion of DPE reaches the best. Then, the hydrogenolysis efficiency of DPE increases slightly with the extension of reaction time. The products are mainly CHL and CHE, when the reaction time reaches 4 h. In the case of products for CHE and CHL to facilitate discussion, our following exploratory experiments all chose 4 h as the reaction time. Then, different reaction temperatures were investigated for the hydrogenation of DPE at 15Ni15Co/SA (Fig. 6b). Only 1.0% of DPE was converted at 120 °C. After increasing the reaction temperature, the conversion of DPE increased, and when it reached 160 °C, the catalyst performance reached the best and no longer changed. The results of the effect of hydrogen pressure indicated DPE was converted, while initial hydrogen pressure was 0.5 MPa, no DCE can be observed in the reaction (Fig. 6c). After increasing the initial hydrogen pressure, the activity of the catalyst is also significantly improved. The selectivity of DCE increases significantly at 2.0 MPa, which indicated that the higher hydrogen pressure could promote CPE to be hydrogenated into DCE instead of the cleavage of CO bonds. Finally, the catalytic activity of 15Ni15Co/SA in different catalyst dosages was investigated (Fig. 6d). It can be seen that the amount of catalysis can significantly improve the activity of the catalyst. When the catalyst dosage reaches 100 mg, the activity of the catalyst no longer changes significantly with the increase of catalyst dosage. The effect of the reduction temperature on the activity of the catalyst is shown in Fig. S4. When the reduction temperature is 500 °C, the catalyst activity reaches the best and no longer varies much with the increase of the reduction temperature. The Lewis basicity of the solvent has a great influence on the hydrogenolysis of DPE, and both protic and aprotic polar solvents have Lewis basicity [22]. The effect of solvents on the performance of catalysts is shown in Table S2. Compared to the protic solvents, DPE is well converted in aprotic polar solvents, the reason for this may be the high Lewis basicity in the proton solvent [22]. The reason for the better hydrogenolysis efficiency of dioxane may be due to the higher solubility [62]. 3.3 Reaction pathway In the initial reaction stage, DPE was only converted at 6.1% in 0.5 h. Meanwhile, the selectivity of CHE and CHL increased slowly in 4 h, while the selectivity of CPE decreased rapidly and then flattened over time, and the selectivity of BEN first increased and then decreased until it disappeared (Fig. 6a), indicating that there are two reaction paths in the catalyst, and due to the high selectivity of CPE in the early stage of the reaction, partial hydrogenation-hydrogenolysis-hydrogenation is the main reaction path for hydrogenation of diphenyl ethers in this catalyst. When single-metal low-supported (15Ni/SA and 15Co/SA) catalysts were used (Table 2, entry 11), PHL was observed compared to other bimetallic catalysts (Table 2, entry 2–3), indicating that the high loading of Co affected the hydrogenation activity of the benzene rings [63]. And a small amount of DCE is also detected. The above experimental results show that the possible reaction path of the hydrogenation of DPE is shown in Fig. 7 . There are small amounts of DCEs that are detected as hydrogenation products of CPE; CPE can be converted by the cleavage of the alkyl Csp3 O bond or the aromatic Csp2 O bond, but considering the high energy of the aromatic Csp2 O bond, the alkyl Csp3 O bond break may be a reasonable reaction route [64,65]. According to the above results, the hydrogenation of DPE catalyzed by 15Ni15Co/SA in 1.4-dioxane media can be carried out in two different reaction pathways: І) BEN and PHL were obtained by the hydrogenolysis of DPE, and then BEN and PHL were hydrogenated into CHE and CHL, respectively; П) First, DPE is hydrogenated into CPE and then converted to CPE to obtain other products (CHL, CHE and DCE). Reaction conditions: DPE 1 mmol, catalyst 100 mg, initial hydrogen pressure 1 MPa, solvent 1.4-dioxane, temperature 160 °C, reaction time 2 h. (PHL: phenol, BEN: benzene, CHL: cyclohexanol, CHE: cyclohexane, CPE: cyclohexyl phenyl ether, DCE: di-cyclohexyl ether) In order to explore the mechanism of Ni and Co metals in the hydrogenation of DPE with Ni and Co metals, the distribution of the product was observed by shortening the reaction time (Fig. 8 ). When SA was used as a catalyst, diphenyl ether was hardly converted at 220 °C and 4 h, suggested that Ni and Co were the main active sites of the catalyst. CPE is the main hydrogenation product of 30Co/SA catalysts, and accompanied by the production of part of BEN and CHL. However, its catalytic activity is low, and only 3% of DPE was converted, indicated that Co helps to activate hydrogen and realize partial hydrogenation of benzene rings. Meanwhile, CPE can also be detected in the product distribution of 30Ni/SA catalyst, but the selectivity is lower compared with BEN and PHL, indicated that the Ni active site can directly act on the CO bond. The main reaction route was direct hydrogenation of DPE to generate BEN and PHL, and then hydrogenation to form CHE and CHL, compared with 30Co/SA catalyst. Although the conversion of DPE was close to 50%, it is difficult to achieve the expected effect. The Ni-Co alloy catalyst formed by replacing the metal Ni with part of the Co metal increased the activity of the catalyst compared to the monometallic catalyst, and also increases the corresponding hydrogenation activity, which indicates that there is a synergistic effect between the Ni and Co metals. The reaction path of DPE hydrogenation reaction is mainly "partial hydrogenation-hydrogenolysis-hydrogenation", supplemented by "direct hydrogenolysis-hydrogenation". The addition of Ni metal forms the active center of the Ni-Co alloy and also weakens the interaction between the active center and the support (Fig. 5) [66], which facilitates the adsorption of H and the dissociation of H2 by the active site of the Ni-Co alloy [60]. Due to the strong CAr-O-CAr bonding energy, it is also relatively easy to hydrogenate the DPE part first, and then break the CO bond, which is also the main reason why the hydrogenation reaction of DPE can be fully converted under relatively mild conditions. Due to the synergistic effect between Ni and Co, the bimetallic catalyst also greatly improves the hydrogenolytic activity of DPE, in addition to Co is mainly responsible for H2 activation while Ni is responsible for ether bond cleavage. 3.4 Stability and versatility of the catalyst The stability of the bimetallic 15Ni15Co/SA catalyst was studied in multiple reaction cycles. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the conversion of DPE and the selectivity of product decreased after five reaction cycles. The catalyst after the fifth cycle is reduced for 4 h in a 500 °C tube furnace under a reduction atmosphere (N2:H2 =9:1, v/v), and the heating rate is the same as in the above experiment. The catalyst was obtained for the sixth cycle experiment, and the performance of the catalyst was basically consistent with the performance of the initial catalyst. In order to explore the causes of changes in catalyst performance, the structure and surface chemical state of the recovered catalyst were compared with that of the fresh prepared catalyst. First of all, the XRD characterization (Fig. 9b) shows that the diffraction peaks of the recovered catalyst before and after the reaction, indicating that the structure of the catalyst before and after the reaction is not destroyed. The result characterization of XPS (Fig. 9c, d), it can be seen that the oxidation state content of Ni and Co after the reaction is significantly higher than the content of Ni and Co oxidation before the reaction, which may be the reason for the decrease in catalyst performance. The above hypothesis is verified by regenerating the catalyst after the fifth cycle (Fig. 9a). It can be concluded that the catalytic performance after regeneration remains basically the same as that of the initial catalyst, which further confirms the above speculation. The analysis results of the analysis of the catalyst before and after the reaction by ICP-OES showed that the Ni and Co contents of catalyst 15Ni15Co/SA remained basically unchanged before and after the reaction (14.4wt% and 13.6wt%, 14.3wt% and 13.8wt%, respectively). The universality of the 15Ni15Co/SA catalyst was studied using the 'α-O-4′ bond and the 'β-O-4′ bond as examples. Benzyl phenyl ether and 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol as the substrate, we find that phenol, methylcyclohexane, ethylbenzene, ethyl-cyclohexane and cyclohexanol are formed as main products (Table 3 ). Under the specific reaction conditions, the catalyst has good hydrogenolysis capacity for both 'α-O-4′ bonds and 'β-O-4′ bonds. 4 Conclusion In this work, a series of bimetallic catalysts with different concentrations of Ni-Co alloys were synthesized by wet immersion method to explore the DPE hydrogenation reaction, and under relatively mild conditions (160 °C, 1 MPa H2, 2 h), the 15Ni15Co/SA catalyst showed the best hydrolytic activity compared with the single metal catalyst, and the improvement of catalyst activity was attributed to the synergistic effect between metals in Ni-Co alloy, which can be confirmed by XPS results. From the results of H2-TPR, it can be seen that after the metal Ni substitutes part of Co to form Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts, the interaction between metal and support is weakened, which is beneficial to the adsorption of H and the dissociation of H2. The hydrogenation of DPE has the main reaction path on bimetallic catalysts as "partial hydrogenation-hydrogenolysis-hydrogenation", while the other reaction path is direct hydrogenation-hydrogenation, in which Co is mainly responsible for the activation of H2 and Ni is mainly responsible for the cleavage of ether bonds. In addition, the catalyst remains stable after reduction and regeneration and has good suitability for hydrogenation of other ether bonds ("α-O-4″ and "β-O-4″ bonds). coredata.dc:description: The selective cleavage of ether bonds by non-noble metal catalysts is crucial for the valorization of lignin. Bimetallic catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation using SiO2-Al2O3 as the supports and Ni and Co as the active metal sites. The prepared bimetal catalysts possess higher catalytic activity than single Ni or Co catalysts and could efficiently cleave the CO bonds of diphenyl ether (DPE), under relatively mild conditions (160 °C, 1 MPa H2, 2 h). The XPS characterization suggested the interactions between Ni and Co in the bimetal catalysts, which could bring synergy effects between metals and increase the catalytic activity. The H2-TPR analysis confirmed that the presence of Ni lowered the reduction temperature of Co oxides in the bimetallic xNiyCo/SA catalyst compared to the monometallic Co/SA catalyst, which would increase the amount of metallic Co. Based on the product distribution, it could be proposed that the hydrogenation of DPE over catalyst 15Ni15Co/SA was mainly via the reaction path of “partial hydrogenation-hydrogenolysis-hydrogenation" process. The catalytic activity of catalyst15Ni15Co/SA could be recovered after regeneration. It also exhibited versatility for the cleavage of other CO bonds.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of diphenyl ethers over NiCo bimetallic catalyst
